html: @parsoyaarihant @moorepants I was trying to make changes to make beam.py compaitable with beams with variable I or E. something like:
text: @parsoyaarihant  @moorepants I was trying to make changes to make beam.py compaitable with beams with variable  `I` or `E`. something like:
[![var_cross.png](https://files.gitter.im/sympy/RichBeamSolvingSystem/862h/thumb/var_cross.png)](https://files.gitter.im/sympy/RichBeamSolvingSystem/862h/var_cross.png)

html: I am kinda confused what I should be a : Piecewise function or a SingularityFunction?
text: I am kinda confused what `I` should be a : `Piecewise` function or a `SingularityFunction`?

html: Also what should be the desired API for that?
text: Also what should be the desired API for that?

html: for now i am making second momemt to be a list of tuples of form(value, start, order, end).
text: for now i am making second momemt to be a list of tuples of form`(value, start, order, end)`.

html: That is for the above beam second_moment would be [(1.5*I, 0, 0, 2), (I, 2, 0, 4)]
text: That is for the above beam `second_moment` would be `[(1.5*I, 0, 0, 2), (I, 2, 0, 4)]`

html: Regarding API, I think it would be good to pass a sympy function I = Inertia(f, x) where x is the length along the beam.
text: Regarding API, I think it would be good to pass a sympy function `I = Inertia(f, x)` where `x` is the length along the beam.

html: And f is the equation of Inertia along the beam.
text: And `f` is the equation of Inertia along the beam.

html: By passing a function, we can represent complex functions of I.
text: By passing a function, we can represent complex functions of `I`.

html: but a f is not continous(as in above case), it has to Piecewise or SingularityFunction like Piecewise((0, x<0), (1.5*I, x<2), (I, x<4))
text: but a `f` is not continous(as in above case), it has to `Piecewise` or `SingularityFunction` like `Piecewise((0, x<0), (1.5*I, x<2), (I, x<4))`

html: so rather than passing it like them I was thinking wouldnt it be easy to pass them the way we pass our load( like [(1.5*I, 0, 0, 2), (I, 2, 0, 4)] for the above one)?
text: so rather than passing it like them I was thinking wouldnt it be easy to pass them the way we pass our `load`( like `[(1.5*I, 0, 0, 2), (I, 2, 0, 4)]` for the above one)?

html: Okay, can we let the user decide which form he wants to pass? i.e. Piecewiseor SingularityFunction?
text: Okay, can we let the user decide which form he wants to pass? i.e. `Piecewise`or `SingularityFunction`?

html: If we are using API of this form: I = Inertia(f, x)
text: If we are using API of this form: `I = Inertia(f, x)`

html: With [(1.5*I, 0, 0, 2), (I, 2, 0, 4)] API the user will not be able to pass non linear Ifunction.
text: With `[(1.5*I, 0, 0, 2), (I, 2, 0, 4)]` API the user will not be able to pass non linear `I`function.

text: Actaully the main problem is coming when we have to integrate  `bending_moment()/I`.

text: appearently terms of form `SingularityFunction/ SingularityFunction` or `SingularityFunction/Piecewise` doesn't integrate well.

html:
Hi everyone!
I have been working on the CrossSection class which intends to integrate the geometry module with the continuum mechanics module. I just created a [WIP] PR #16964.

So the main problem as I also mentioned in my blog was defining the first moment of area of a geometry i.e whether to calculate it for the extreme layer only or to calculate it in terms of y where y would be the distance of that layer from the bottom of the cross-section.

Similar is the dilemma for section_modulus. I have tried calculating section_modulus in terms of y.
Please have a look in the PR.
If this works well then, a similar calculation can be done for the first moment of area.
Need some views.
text:
Hi everyone!
I have been working on the `CrossSection` class which intends to integrate the geometry module with the continuum mechanics module. I just created a [WIP]  PR #16964.

So the main problem as I also mentioned in [my blog](https://ishanaj.wordpress.com/2019/06/03/gsoc19-week-1-starting-with-the-crosssection-class/) was defining the first moment of area of a geometry i.e whether to calculate it  for the extreme layer only or to calculate it in terms of `y` where y would be the distance of that layer from the bottom of the cross-section.

Similar is the dilemma for `section_modulus`.  I have tried calculating `section_modulus` in terms of `y`.
Please have a look in the PR.
If  this works well then, a similar calculation can be done for the first moment of area.
Need some views.

html: Okay, left a comment on PR.
text: Okay, left a comment on PR.

html: Is it a bad idea to plot a verticle line at x = a instead of SingularityFunction(x, a, -1) inside _draw_point_load?
text: Is it a bad idea to plot a verticle line at `x = a` instead of  `SingularityFunction(x, a, -1)`  inside  `_draw_point_load`?

html:
Is it a bad idea to plot a verticle line at x = a instead of SingularityFunction(x, a, -1) inside _draw_point_load?

But we would also require an arrowhead in that case.I am not sure if there is a way to plot arrowhead or annotations using sympy' plot().
Also, it will be difficult to plot a rectangle (for beam) and markers (for supports) via sympy.plot().
Are we intending to use _backend attribute here?
I haven't used the _backendattribute before and am not sure that it will be helpful or not.
text:
> Is it a bad idea to plot a verticle line at `x = a` instead of  `SingularityFunction(x, a, -1)`  inside  `_draw_point_load`?

But we would also require an arrowhead in that case.I am not sure if there is a way to plot arrowhead or annotations using sympy' plot().
Also, it will be difficult to plot a rectangle (for beam) and markers (for supports)  via sympy.plot().
Are we intending to use `_backend` attribute here?
I haven't used the `_backend `attribute before and am not sure that it will be helpful or not.

Are we intending to use _backend attribute here?

Yeah I don’t think `sympy.plot` can create arrowheads, going with  `_backend` seems better.
